document.title: On the spectra of strong power graphs of finite groups

creator.personname: Xuanlong MaE-mail address: xuanlma@mail.bnu.edu.cn. Sch. Math. Sci. & Lab. Math. Com. Sys., Beijing Normal University, Beijing, 100875, China

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: We give the characteristic polynomial of the distance or adjacency matrix of the strong power graph of a finite group, and compute its distance and adjacency spectrum.
Key words: strong power graph; cyclic group; characteristic polynomial; spectrum.

para.p: GBKsong

Given a connected graph Γ, denote by ⁢V(Γ) and ⁢E(Γ) the vertex set and edge set, respectively. Let =⁢V(Γ){v1,v2,…,vn}. The distance between the vertices vi and vj, denoted by ⁢dΓ(vi,vj), is the length of the shortest path between them. The diameter of Γ, denoted by diam(Γ), is the maximum distance between any pair of vertices of Γ. The set of neighbours of a vertex vi in Γ is denoted by ⁢NΓ(vi), that is, =⁢NΓ(vi){∈vj⁢V(Γ):∈{vi,vj}⁢E(Γ)}.

The distance matrix ⁢D(Γ) of Γ is the ×nn matrix, indexed by ⁢V(Γ), such that =⁢D(Γ)vi,vj⁢dΓ(vi,vj). The characteristic polynomial =⁢Θ(Γ,x)|-⁢xI⁢D(Γ)| is the distance characteristic polynomial of Γ. Note that ⁢D(Γ) is symmetric. The distance characteristic polynomial has real roots μ1≥μ2≥…≥μn. If μi1≥μi2≥…≥μit are the distinct roots of ⁢Θ(Γ,x), then the D-spectrum of Γ can be written as

Math.text: spec _ D * Gamma = Array[[mu _ i _ 1, mu _ i _ 2, dots, mu _ i _ t], [m _ 1, m _ 2, dots, m _ t]]

para.p: where mj is the algebraic multiplicity of μij. Clearly =∑=j1tmjn. The adjacency matrix ⁢A(Γ) of Γ is a ×nn matrix and indexed by ⁢V(Γ). The ⁢ij-th entry of ⁢A(Γ) is 1 if the vertices vi and vj are adjacent, otherwise it is 0. Denote by ⁢Φ(Γ,x) the characteristic polynomial of ⁢A(Γ). Similarly, we define the adjacency spectrum ⁢spec(Γ) of Γ. The largest root of ⁢Θ(Γ,x)(resp. ⁢Φ(Γ,x)) is called the distance spectral radius(resp. adjacency spectral radius) of Γ.

Let G denote a finite group of order n. The power graph of G was introduced by Chakrabarty et al. [[2]], which has the vertex set G and two distinct elements are adjacent if one is a power of the other. Motivated by this, Singh and Manilal [[3]] defined the strong power graphs as a generalization of the power graphs. The strong power graph ⁢Ps(G) of G is a graph whose vertex set consists of the elements of G and two distinct vertices x and y are adjacent if =xn1yn2 for some positive integers <n1,n2n. Very recently, Bhuniya and Berathe [[1]] investigated the Laplacian of strong power graphs.
In this paper we study the characteristic polynomial of the distance or adjacency matrix of the strong power graph of a finite group, and compute its distance and adjacency spectrum.
Throughout this section G denotes a finite group, and Zn stands for the cyclic group of order n. We always assume =Zn{0,1,…,-n1}. For strong power graphs we have the following proposition.

p.text: (1) If G is not cyclic, then ⁢Ps(G) is complete.
(2) ⁢Ps(Zn) is not connected if and only if n is a prime number.

para.p: (3) =⁢N⁢Ps(Zn)(0){∈kZn:≠m0,≠(m,n)1}, and the subgraph of ⁢Ps(Zn) induced by ∖Zn{0} is complete. In particular, diam=(⁢Ps(Zn))2 if n is not a prime number.
Now we find the characteristic polynomial of the distance matrix associated with the strong power graph ⁢Ps(Zn) for any composite number n.

Math.text: Theta * open-interval@(P _ s * Z _ n, x) = (x + 1) ^ (n - 3) * (((x ^ 3 + (3 - n) * x ^ 2 + (3 - 2 * n - 3 * phi * n) * x) - phi * n ^ 2 - phi * n * (4 - n) - n) + 1)

para.p: Proof. Write =⁢ϕ(n)t and =k-n⁢ϕ(n)1. By Proposition 2.1, the distance matrix ⁢D(⁢Ps(Zn)) is the ×nn matrix given below, where the rows and columns are indexed in order by the vertices in ⁢N⁢Ps(Zn)(0) then all generator elements of Zn, and 0 is in last position.

Math.text: D * P _ s * Z _ n = Array[[0, 1, dots, 1, 1, dots, 1, 1], [1, 0, dots, 1, 1, ldots, 1, 1], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [1, 1, ldots, 0, 1, ldots, 1, 1], [1, 1, ldots, 1, 0, ldots, 1, 2], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [1, 1, ldots, 1, 1, ldots, 0, 2], [1, 1, ldots, 1, 2, ldots, 2, 0]]

para.p: The characteristic polynomial of ⁢D(⁢Ps(Zn)) is

Math.text: Theta * open-interval@(P _ s * Z _ n, x) = absolute-value@(Array[[x, - 1, dots, - 1, - 1, dots, - 1, - 1], [- 1, x, dots, - 1, - 1, ldots, - 1, - 1], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [- 1, - 1, ldots, x, - 1, ldots, - 1, - 1], [- 1, - 1, ldots, - 1, x, ldots, - 1, - 2], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [- 1, - 1, ldots, - 1, - 1, ldots, x, - 2], [- 1, - 1, ldots, - 1, - 2, ldots, - 2, x]])

para.p: Subtract the first column from the columns 2,3,…,n of (1) to obtain (2):

Math.text: (x + 1) ^ (k - 1) * absolute-value@(Array[[x, - 1, dots, - 1, - 1 - x, dots, - 1 - x, - 1 - x], [- 1, 1, dots, 0, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [- 1, 0, ldots, 1, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, x + 1, ldots, 0, - 1], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, 0, ldots, x + 1, - 1], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, ldots, - 1, x + 1]])

para.p: Adding the rows 2,3,…,-n1 to the first row of (2). Then adding columns 2,3,…,k to the first column, we arrive at the determinant (3):

Math.text: (x + 1) ^ (k - 1) * absolute-value@(Array[[(x - n) + 2, 0, dots, 0, 0, dots, 0, - 1 - x - t], [0, 1, dots, 0, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [0, 0, ldots, 1, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, x + 1, ldots, 0, - 1], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, 0, ldots, x + 1, - 1], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, ldots, - 1, x + 1]])

para.p: Subtract the first column from the last column of (3). Then subtract the row +k1 from the rows +k2,+k3,…,n to obtain (4):

Math.text: (x + 1) ^ (n - 3) * absolute-value@(Array[[(x - n) + 2, 0, dots, 0, 0, 0, dots, 0, ((- 2 * x) + k) - 2], [0, 1, dots, 0, 0, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [0, 0, ldots, 1, 0, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, x + 1, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, 1, ldots, 0, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, 0, ldots, 1, 0], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - 2 - x, - 1, ldots, - 1, x + 2]])

para.p: Adding the rows +k2,+k3,…,-n1 to the last row of (4), we get (5):

Math.text: (x + 1) ^ (n - 3) * absolute-value@(Array[[(x - n) + 2, 0, dots, 0, 0, 0, dots, 0, ((- 2 * x) + k) - 2], [0, 1, dots, 0, 0, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [0, 0, ldots, 1, 0, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, x + 1, 0, ldots, 0, 0], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, 1, ldots, 0, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, 0, ldots, 1, 0], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - x - t - 1, 0, ldots, 0, x + 2]])

para.p: Expand it along the first row to obtain (6):
where

Math.text: absolute-value@(A) = absolute-value@(Array[[0, 1, dots, 0, 0, 0, ldots, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots], [0, 0, ldots, 1, 0, 0, ldots, 0], [- 1, 0, ldots, 0, x + 1, 0, ldots, 0], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, 1, ldots, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - 1, 0, ldots, 1], [0, 0, ldots, 0, - x - t - 1, 0, ldots, 0]])

para.p: In (7) the determinant has order -n1. Interchange the row -k1 and the last row of (7). Then expand it along the first column to obtain |A| as follows:

Math.text: absolute-value@(A) = (- 1) ^ n * (- x - t - 1)

para.p: It follows that
This completes our proof. □
By Proposition 2.1, one has that ⁢Ps(G) is connected if and only if G is not cyclic, or ≅GZn for some composite number n. Now we may compute the D-spectrum of any connected strong power graph.

p.text: If G is not cyclic, then

Math.text: spec _ D * P _ s * G = Array[[n - 1, - 1], [1, n - 1]]

p.text: If ≅GZn for some composite number n, then ⁢specD(⁢Ps(Zn)) is

Math.text: Array[[- 1, ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@((theta / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 + 9 * phi * n))) / 3, ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@(((theta + 2 * pi) / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 + 9 * phi * n))) / 3, ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@(((theta - 2 * pi) / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 + 9 * phi * n))) / 3], [n - 3, 1, 1, 1]]

para.p: Proof. Note that if G is not cyclic then ⁢Ps(G) is complete. Thus, it suffices to compute the distance spectrum of ⁢Ps(Zn) for some composite number n. Let

Suppose that =⁢f(-1)0. Then =⁢ϕ(n)(-n⁢ϕ(n)1)0. It follows that =⁢ϕ(n)-n1. Namely n is a prime number, a contradiction. This implies that D-spectrum of ⁢Ps(Zn) has -1 with multiplicity -n3 by Theorem 2.2. Note that the canonical solutions of any quadratic and cubic equation. We conclude that ⁢f(x) has three pairwise distinct roots, as presented above. □

p.text: For any composite number n, the distance spectral radius of ⁢Ps(Zn) is

Math.text: ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@((theta / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 + 9 * phi * n))) / 3

para.p: For any positive integer n, the adjacency matrix ⁢A(⁢Ps(Zn)) is given below, where the rows and columns are indexed in order by the vertices in ⁢N⁢Ps(Zn)(0) then all generator elements of Zn, and 0 is in last position. Note that ⁢N⁢Ps(Zn)(0) may be the empty set.

Math.text: A * P _ s * Z _ n = Array[[0, 1, dots, 1, 1, dots, 1, 1], [1, 0, dots, 1, 1, ldots, 1, 1], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [1, 1, ldots, 0, 1, ldots, 1, 1], [1, 1, ldots, 1, 0, ldots, 1, 0], [vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots, ddots, vdots, vdots], [1, 1, ldots, 1, 1, ldots, 0, 0], [1, 1, ldots, 1, 0, ldots, 0, 0]]

para.p: An argument similar to the one used in the computing of ⁢Θ(⁢Ps(Zn),x), we get ⁢Φ(⁢Ps(Zn),x).

Math.text: Phi * open-interval@(P _ s * Z _ n, x) = (x + 1) ^ (n - 3) * (x ^ 3 + (3 - n) * x ^ 2 + ((3 - 2 * n) + phi * n) * x + (n - phi * n - 1) * (phi * n - 1))
Phi * open-interval@(P _ s * Z _ p, x) = x * (x + 1) ^ (p - 2) * ((x + 2) - p)

para.p: As an application of Theorem 2.5, we may obtain the adjacency spectrum of the strong power graph of a finite group.

p.text: If G is not cyclic, then

Math.text: spec * P _ s * G = Array[[n - 1, - 1], [1, n - 1]]

p.text: If ≅GZp for some prime number p, then
If ≅GZn for some composite number n, then ⁢spec(⁢Ps(Zn)) is

Math.text: Array[[- 1, ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@((theta / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 - 3 * phi * n))) / 3, ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@(((theta + 2 * pi) / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 - 3 * phi * n))) / 3, ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@(((theta - 2 * pi) / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 - 3 * phi * n))) / 3], [n - 3, 1, 1, 1]]

p.text: For any composite number n, the adjacency spectral radius of ⁢Ps(Zn) is

Math.text: ((n - 3) + 2 * cosine@((theta / 3) * square-root@(n ^ 2 - 3 * phi * n))) / 3

para.p: This research is supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (11271047, 11371204).

G. Suresh Singh and K. Manilal, Some generalities on power graphs and strong power graphs, Int. J. Contemp. Math. Sciences 5 (2010) 2723–2730.
